Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a string of urgent Slack messages from the architects. The launch date had been moved up—again—and now everyone was waiting on me to make decisions about the new features. My inbox was a mess of red exclamation marks and “ASAP” subject lines. But just as I started typing a response, my girlfriend’s voice cut through the haze. We’d been arguing for hours, voices rising, words sharper than I intended. Now, she was sitting across from me, eyes red, asking if we were even right for each other anymore. I could see the pain in her face, the expectation that I’d drop everything and help us find a way through this. But the pressure from work was crushing; people were literally blocked until I responded. My heart pounded as I looked between her and my laptop, feeling like I was being torn in two. I wanted to be the boyfriend who could fix things, who could make her feel secure. But I was also the developer everyone was counting on. I didn’t know which crisis to face first.
